title: Entitled friend plans a last-minute wedding on a weekday, then throws a tantrum when her best friend's husband can't get PTO: 'It’s happening in only 8 weeks'
description: Brides think that everyone is supposed to just bend over backwards for their wedding day. Sure, it's a big deal to get married, but if your "Big Day" falls on a weekday, expect the employed populous from your guest list to be secretly cursing your nuptials. Apparently, this bride wasn't so accommodating or understanding with her guests after planning a last-minute wedding with 8 weeks' notice, because she was furious when she found out her best friend's husband wouldn't be attending. She wanted him to risk his career for the sake of her weekday wedding, all because she had forgotten what it's like to be employed, ask for PTO, and get denied…
author: Jesse Kessenheimer
excerpt: Entitled friend plans a last-minute wedding on a weekday, then throws a tantrum when her best friend's husband can't get PTO: 'It’s happening in only 8 weeks' - The internet has generated a huge amount of laughs from cats and FAILS. And we all out of cats.
text: We Americans only get 10 days of PTO every year. The European mind can hardly comprehend it, but at most of our jobs, that's the national standard for vacation time. If you've spent any length of time in the workforce, you know that those PTO days are precious and must be used wisely, so when this new father used up all of his vacation time, PTO, leave, and sick days to help his wife with their newborn, they cashed out of their entire supply of paid leave. And when this new mom's bestie decided to throw a last-minute wedding, there was nothing left. Too bad, and too late, Sweetie—nobody wants to go to your Wednesday wedding anyway!
html:
We Americans only get 10 days of PTO every year. The European mind can hardly comprehend it, but at most of our jobs, that's the national standard for vacation time. If you've spent any length of time in the workforce, you know that those PTO days are precious and must be used wisely, so when this new father used up all of his vacation time, PTO, leave, and sick days to help his wife with their newborn, they cashed out of their entire supply of paid leave. And when this new mom's bestie decided to throw a last-minute wedding, there was nothing left. 

Too bad, and too late, Sweetie—nobody wants to go to your Wednesday wedding anyway!
